text:
Hey folks :wave:

Was wondering, what are your best internal linking strategies/best practices for getting better at SERPs?

elements.text: Hey folks
Was wondering, what are your best internal linking strategies/best practices for getting better at SERPs?

text:
I find async 100x more productive. We simply use Slack (appropriately through threads) to build from ideas to execution all the time.

On reflection, the idea of getting together in a room and forcing that hour to be when you think of new ideas is absurd.

The addition of Miro or InDesign to draw things out helps at latter stages too.

elements.text:

text:
Before I knew what internal linking was, I did this from from memory. If I was writing a blog post and knew something linkable existed in our content bank, I'd link to it.

When I learned what internal linking actually was and why it was useful, I dedicated an entire day to making sure everything was linked up as best as possible.

Started with a list of keyphrases we targeted for every existing blog posts. Cross referenced through site:<http://website.com|website.com> keyword and updated everything.

Now I include internal linking as the first step in my content promotion process. So before it goes on social media or I start building backlinks, I ensure relevant internal links are made.

elements.text:

Started with a list of keyphrases we targeted for every existing blog posts. Cross referenced through site:website.com keyword and updated everything.

Now I include internal linking as the first step in my content promotion process. So before it goes on social media or I start building backlinks, I ensure relevant internal links are made.

text: This is so interesting. Many of our clients are agencies, and they often expect 24- or 48-hour turnaround on revisions. We've just started talking about setting some boundaries there, in order to give our freelancers (and ourselves) more breathing room. Thanks for all the input -- it's really helpful.

text: +1 to everything Dom said. I'll add that your annual content audit should consider looking at top performing content and identify opportunities to update/improve internal linking.

text:
Who feels like they know what it means to be successful in their role?

I recently switched roles at ActiveCampaign (from director of content to director of growth) and the new role has come with *much* more clarity in terms of metrics and objectives.

I've been thinking of writing about what it means to have clear objectives in a role, so I'm curious — do you feel like you have clear objectives (not just numbers)? What are they?

text: Dave Gerhardt has a good copywriting class as part of his patreon group. I think the class was an extra 20 bucks. It was about an hour and I felt like it was really worth it. <https://www.patreon.com/davegerhardt>

text:
Situation: You just replaced an external SEO consultant and your a content team of one. You have no paid SEO/content tools (yet) and there's money for something. *What paid content/SEO tools would you get?*

My thoughts were:
• Ahrefs
• Some tool that helps with building backlinks

elements.text: Situation: You just replaced an external SEO consultant and your a content team of one. You have no paid SEO/content tools (yet) and there's money for something.
What paid content/SEO tools would you get?
My thoughts were:
Ahrefs
Some tool that helps with building backlinks

text: <@UJJFDTN8G> - when you would do site:<http://website.com|website.com> and then enter the keyword were you trying to determine what that page or whole website was ranking for?

elements.text: - when you would do site:website.com and then enter the keyword were you trying to determine what that page or whole website was ranking for?

text: ahrefs and clearscope probably

elements.text: ahrefs and clearscope probably

text: Clearscope / Frase to help with content production (assuming you'll have resources to get that done, too)

elements.text: Clearscope / Frase to help with content production (assuming you'll have resources to get that done, too)

text: Honestly, I wouldn't start with tools. I'd look at your search console and see where your gaps are in the customer lifecycle. Then, talk to product, sales, and support to see how to fill those gaps. You're new. Dive in deep with the subject matter experts at your company. All that other jazz can come in next quarter.

elements.text: Honestly, I wouldn't start with tools. I'd look at your search console and see where your gaps are in the customer lifecycle. Then, talk to product, sales, and support to see how to fill those gaps. You're new. Dive in deep with the subject matter experts at your company. All that other jazz can come in next quarter.

text: I also really like Semrush if you want an alternative to Ahrefs. And Clearscope if your budget allows for it.

elements.text: I also really like Semrush if you want an alternative to Ahrefs. And Clearscope if your budget allows for it.

text: Anyone have suggestions on how to wrangle all our content and content process? I'm trying to wrangle our 500 post english blog and associated offers for those pages, sort out which posts have been translated into a half dozen other languages and build out a future content calendar.

elements.text: Anyone have suggestions on how to wrangle all our content and content process? I'm trying to wrangle our 500 post english blog and associated offers for those pages, sort out which posts have been translated into a half dozen other languages and build out a future content calendar.

text:
What's the struggle? Auditing, inventory, deciding what to keep/upgrade/prune?

Airtable is good for 'exploring' the content in ways that G Sheets doesn't handle well. I like URL Profiler for the quantitative assessment of links/social/etc.

Or is the struggle with new content, making sure you're not cannibalizing old content, etc?

elements.text:

Airtable is good for 'exploring' the content in ways that G Sheets doesn't handle well. I like URL Profiler for the quantitative assessment of links/social/etc.

Or is the struggle with new content, making sure you're not cannibalizing old content, etc?

text: What's brought this to a head is that I'm doing a big migration/consolidation project (moving from a bunch of standalone Wordpress sites to a single Hubspot blog site), and that I've taken over responsibility from the regional teams for getting content translated (managed through our translation agency).

elements.text: What's brought this to a head is that I'm doing a big migration/consolidation project (moving from a bunch of standalone Wordpress sites to a single Hubspot blog site), and that I've taken over responsibility from the regional teams for getting content translated (managed through our translation agency).

text: But here's the issue - we'll start with a post in English and then to manage it through say French, German and Spanish translation is like 6 different jobs (1 for text content translation and 1 for graphics translation) and they all get done at different times and have different processes/teams that need to approve them and then actually publish them.

elements.text: But here's the issue - we'll start with a post in English and then to manage it through say French, German and Spanish translation is like 6 different jobs (1 for text content translation and 1 for graphics translation) and they all get done at different times and have different processes/teams that need to approve them and then actually publish them.

text:
I'd turn to Airtable and set up connections between the content to make it easier to jump across languages. But regardless of workflow/tool it'll be a headache to set it all up. =/

Free option would be primary spreadsheet with each post as a row, each language as a column and links to the published url/draft/whatever in the cell.
